Well, if categories were removed, there wouldn't be any categories.
People would judge books not on what the content is, but how well it's handled.
I mean, it's pretty, you know, if you come to think, if you think about it, it's pretty unlikely to say that
because you're writing about the future or because you're writing about a world that isn't,
or using speculative material that necessarily all the books that are written that way
would be inferior to contemporary novels in terms of the writing, in terms of how good it is.
And if there weren't any categories, books would be judged on their relative qualities and not on their content.
What about Europe? I understand that you do very well over there, your reputation.
Did they do it differently? I mean, did they categorize that way too?
They do and they don't. France is my best country and that's a good example.
And there, every book is also categorized.
In other words, they have what they call collections. Every publisher has various collections of novels.
They'll have a science fiction collection.
They'll have a collection of so-called mainstream novels or something that is the collection of a particular editor
who even has a name on the collection.
So this collection reflects this editor's taste and it's labeled that way and it's given a name.
So in a sense, everything is categorized.
But there's less approbation between the categories.
Since everything is categorized under a name chosen by the, you know, to identify this line of these,
this bunch of books with the editor was actually editing them.
There's not so much stigma in having a category because everything is that kind of category.
Although everything is categorized, the categories have been more equal.
Also, they give you a lot, you know, they have much more respect.
They seem to, you know, they understand that there's no particular, you know, that a lot of everything is crap.
But there's no particular reason why a science fiction novel shouldn't be as good as anything else.
It's still going to be a science fiction novel. It's that good.
And so while they do still pay attention to categories, they do not automatically discount something because it's science fiction.
It was talking to a friend of mine this morning who was over in Europe a few years ago and he said, you know,
that he'd noticed many books by, you know, you over their translations.
But yet he had not read you over here, which implied to me that you must be better known or at least more appreciated.
I just came back from three weeks in France doing book publicity in Paris.
And the publicity for the record I made there.
You know, I think not only am I, not only do I think that I am more, you know, relatively more known in France than I am here,
but I think that writers in general are more important in France than they are here.
Writing is more literature is more central to the popular culture of France saying that it is the popular culture of the United States in general.
People have a different attitude towards writing and towards writers.
There's a certain generalized American anti-intellectualism anyway.
This does not exist in France.
In other Europe, it's this atmosphere of anti-intellectualism.
And so writers in general are considered more important in France.
And I'm considered more important in science fiction.
It's a different, it's a deep cultural attitude.
I think that reflects partly the fact that my book is more popular there, partly the fact that it's more important to be writer.
Okay, what about just on this question of science, how it's considered by the public and so forth.
Do you think the movies and television hurt the image of science fiction?
I mean, to be treated as a serious literature, do you think they detract or hurt it?
I don't know. I don't think they, not really.
I mean, the image of science fiction in that respect has been very bad anyway.
I don't think the movies really add to the image, but I don't think they detract from it either.
If there are some better, more sophisticated movies, they might help.
As it is, it's just kind of neutral publicity, people more aware that it exists.
I think it's positive and will prove to be positive in the long range,
because a lot of people are being introduced to the imagery of science fiction,
with which they are unfamiliar through these movies.
And if you look at the evolution in the movies, you find that in the earlier science fiction movies,
if you're going into space or whatever, you had to spend like half an hour setting the thing,
this is a spaceship, it takes off from the Earth, people float around it, you know,
and you have to familiarize the audience with all this unfamiliar imagery.
Now they can just start a movie bang right off any galaxy far away.
Boom. Here's a spaceship in the stromo pow, you know,
in other words, the first half hour of the conventional old-time science fiction movie is gone,
because people are now familiar with this imagery.
And I think these movies have brought a lot of new people into familiarity with these images.
They made these images part of the popular culture.
These movies were mainly aimed at kids and adolescents.
And years from now, assuming that these people never read anything,
they'll be ready to read science fiction of a more serious kind,
assuming they're ready to read literature of a more serious kind or a lot,
because they'll be familiar with the material, familiar with the literature,
it won't seem strange and weird to them because they will have grown up with it.
That's why I think magazines, even magazines like Star Wars,
in that sense will have a long-term positive impact.
